Byline: GARRY OWEN (Gordon Brown)

GOLAN will line-up for the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe after an impressive win at Longchamp yesterday.

The Sagitta 2000 Guineas winner, trained by Sir Michael Stoute, beat French Derby winner Anabaa Blue in the Prix Niel Casino Barriere d'Enghien les Bains.

Third was French-trained Chichicastenango, with the other British challenger, Storming Home, from the Barry Hills yard, last of the seven runners.

Golan's jockey Kieren Fallon said: "He was in front too soon but I got a perfect opening and I had to take that.

"He felt good today. He loves it round here. He's definitely a real Arc horse.

"He will need a low draw but I think a good gallop will suit him. I am just looking forward to the race."

Golan had been off the course since finishing third to Galileo in the Budweiser Irish Derby in June. He had earlier been second to the same horse in the Vodafone Derby at Epsom.

But while it was an impressive performance, I didn't see anything that would put me off backing St Leger winner Milan in Paris.

Hightori consolidated his position as a leading fancy for the Arc when winning the Prix Foy Gray d'Albion Barriere under Gerald Mosse.

But it was no walkover for the horse who was forced to dig deep for his victory over Idaho Quest.

The win will, however, have put Hightori right for the big race in just under three weeks.

Unbeaten Aquarelliste scored a fourth straight win of the season when landing the Prix Vermeille Hermitage Barriere.

The filly scored impressively under Dominique Boeuf for trainer Elie Lellouche.

The three-year-old, racing in the Daniel Wildenstein colours, beat Diamilina, who was bidding for a five-timer for trainer Andre Fabre.

Mot Juste, under Richard Hughes, tried to make much of the running for trainer Ed Dunlop but could not withstand the challenge of the first three and finished fourth.

The filly, winner of the Listed Pretty Polly Stakes at Newmarket in May, had been disappointing when eighth in the Yorkshire Oaks at the Ebor meeting last month.

Ladbrokes go: 5-2 Sakhee (with a run), 7-2 Aquarelliste, 4 Hightori, 6 Milan, 10 Maille Pistol, Golan 12 bar.

Meanwhile, Mediterranean is back home at Ballydoyle and awaiting X-rays on a tendon injury suffered in Saturday's St Leger.

"His off fore leg was cast after the race and he came home with the rest of the horses last night," said trainer Aidan O'Brien.

"They'll probably take off the cast for the X-rays and discover whether the tendon is ruptured or not," he added of the Tote Ebor winner.
